Article.Abstract: Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus infection of H-2(b) mice generates a strong CD8(+) CTL response mainly directed toward three immunodominant epitopes, one of which, gp33, is presented by both H-2D(b) and H-2K(b) MHC class I molecules. This CTL response acts as a selective agent for the emergence of viral escape variants. These variants generate altered peptide ligands (APLs) that, when presented by class I MHC molecules, antagonize CTL recognition and ultimately allow the virus to evade the cellular immune response. The emergence of APLs of the gp33 epitope is particularly advantageous for LCMV, as it allows viral escape in the context of both H-2D(b) and H-2K(b) MHC class I molecules. We have determined crystal structures of three different APLs of gp33 in complex with both H-2D(b) and H-2K(b). Comparison between these APL/MHC structures and those of the index gp33 peptide/MHC reveals the structural basis for three different strategies used by LCMV viral escape mutations: 1) conformational changes in peptide and MHC residues that are potential TCR contacts, 2) impairment of APL binding to the MHC peptide binding cleft, and 3) introduction of subtle changes at the TCR/pMHC interface, such as the removal of a single hydroxyl group.
Article.ArticleTitle: Determination of structural principles underlying three different modes of lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus escape from CTL recognition.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Medical Biochemistry and Biophysics, Karolinska Institute, Stockholm, Sweden.

Epitope.EpitopeName: F6L analog of LCMV immunodominant epitope gp33

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope differs from gp33 natural epitope by two substitutions at the C-terminal C9M and F6L. Protein name is taken from Hudrisier et al. (1997) Virology 234: 62 [PMID: 9234947].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Mutant peptide F6L did not bind H-2Kb on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: "In the H-2Db/gp33 complex [PDB: 1S7U], both residues p4Y and p6F project out of the peptide binding cleft, acting as potential main TCR contacts. The escape mutants pY4F[PDB: 1S7X] and pF6L [PDB: 1S7V] could thus be explained by impaired TCR recognition rather than by impaired MHC binding. However, the structural impacts of these two conservative substitutions are different. The pY4F mutation does not result in any modifications other than the removal of the tyrosine hydroxyl group, whereas the conserved pF6L substitution results in changes in the potential TCR contact residues that probably affect the sensitive regions of the TCR through direct sterical clashes and/or the introduction of cavities at the TCR/pMHC interface. The pF6L mutation results in shifts in the central portion variant peptide (residues p4 to p7). The introduction of a less bulky leucine side chain causes a subtle movement of this portion of the peptide toward the α1 domain. The largest movements take place in residues p4Y and p6L. The movements of residues p4 and p6 would most likely result in the creation of cavities at the pMHC/p14TCR interface and/or clashes with the CDR3α or CDR3β of the TCR. Finally, the shift introduced in the main chain of residue p6 induces small movements in residues S150, A152, and H155 of the α2 domain toward the mutated peptide. Most of these residues have been identified as TCR contacts." Contacts here are provided as in the paper describing the structure [PDB: 1N5A] [PMID: 12479822] with no modifications as described in the curated paper.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: There are two complexes in the asymmetric unit.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: In H-2Kb/index gp33 [PDB: 1S7Q], the phenylalanine residue at position 6 of gp33 (p6F) projects down into the C pocket, composed of residues V9, F74, V97, S99, Q114, and Y116. A change from F to L at this position results in a shorter and less bulky residue that does not fit the hydrophobic C pocket as well as phenylalanine, impairing the binding of the mutated peptide. A comparison of the interface between the peptide and the H-2Kb binding cleft in both the index and the pF6L structures also reveals the presence of a large cavity within the C pocket in the latter structure that is not present in H-2Kb/index gp33. Thus, although the pF6L mutation does not introduce major structural changes at the surface of the MHC/peptide interface, it alters the optimal dwell of interaction between the TCR and the MHC/peptide complex. Contacts here are provided as in the paper describing [PDB: 1N59] structure [PMID: 12479822] with modifications described in the curated reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Mutant peptide F6L bound H-2Db on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.

Epitope.EpitopeName: V3L analog of LCMV immunodominant epitope gp33

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope differs from gp33 natural epitope by two substitutions at the C-terminal C9M and V3L. Protein name is taken from Hudrisier et al. (1997) Virology 234: 62 [PMID: 9234947].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Mutant peptide V3L bound H-2Kb on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.
Mutant peptide V3L bound H-2Db on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.
There are four complexes in the asymmetric unit.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: "The side chain of the secondary anchor position p3V projects down into the C-pocket of H-2Db formed by residues Q97, S99, L114, H155, Y156, and Y159. The structures of H-2Db/index gp33 [PDB: 1S7U] and H-2Db/gp33 (V3L) (this structure) H chains are fairly similar. However, the pV3L mutation results in a reduced binding of the peptide to H-2Db, in accordance with other mutational results from V to A at this position. Introduction of the larger leucine side chain through the pV3L mutation results in a small movement of the peptide toward the α1 domain. The Cα shifts in the peptide occur in residues p2A, p3L, and p4Y. The V3L substitution also affects the positioning of the side chain of p4Y, a potential main TCR interacting peptide residue that moves slightly upward. Indeed, the pV3L mutation reduces the affinity of the H-2Db/gp33/p14 TCR interaction by >40-fold. The pV3L mutation also leads to the movement of the side chain of residue H155 within and over the peptide binding cleft, keeping its hydrogen bond interaction with the carbonyl of p4Y." Contacts here are provided as in the paper describing [PDB: 1N5A] structure [PMID: 12479822] with no modifications as described in the curated paper.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The coordinates for the first N-terminal residue of the peptide were not resolved in the structure.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: The side chain of residue p3V in the gp33 index peptide points toward the negatively charged B pocket of H-2Kb composed of residues Y7, V9, E24, Y45, and N70. Residues E63 and K66 are situated above this pocket; K66 is involved in hydrogen bond interactions with the backbone carbonyl of p3V. Here again, both H-2Kb structures are very similar, with an r.m.s.d. of 0.14 Å for the Cα atoms of residues 1–182 that correspond to the α1 and α2 regions of the H chain. However subtle local structural modifications appear in α1 residues in the mutated structure. All the hydrogen bond interactions described in the structure of H-2Kb/index gp33 are retained in the structure of H-2Kb/gp33 (V3L). As a consequence, H chain residue R155 undergoes a small movement to maintain its hydrogen bond interactions with the hydroxyl group of p4Y. The changes observed for the side chain of residue R155 in the pV3L mutation are similar to those described for pY4F, but with a smaller magnitude, where the Nε atom moves 1.0 Å toward the C terminus of the peptide. Residues E63, K66, and R155, which are affected by the pV3L mutation, have been shown to act as TCR contacts in crystal structures of H-2Kb/TCR complexes. Contacts here are provided as in the paper describing [PDB: 1N59] structure PMID: 12479822] with modifications described in the curated reference.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Index peptide gp33 bound H-2Kb on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.
Index peptide gp33 bound H-2Db on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.

Epitope.EpitopeName: Y4F analog of LCMV immunodominant epitope gp33

EpitopeRelatedObject.RelatedObjectType: The epitope is an analog of:

Epitope.EpitopeComments: The epitope differs from gp33 natural epitope by two substitutions at the C-terminal C9M and Y4F. Protein name is taken from Hudrisier et al. (1997) Virology 234: 62 [PMID: 9234947].

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Coordinates for the first N-terminal residue of the peptide were not determined. There are two complexes in the asymmetric unit.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: Tyrosine at position 4 (p4Y) in gp33 [PDB: 1S7Q] projects down into the D pocket of H-2Kb formed by residues Q114, E152, L156, and Y159, where it is involved in the formation of three hydrogen bonds with the side chains of E152 and R155. The side chain of p4Y is further stabilized by hydrophobic interactions with the side chains of Y159 and p6F, whereas the main chain forms a hydrogen bond with N70. The structures of H-2Kb in complex with either the gp33 index peptide or the gp33 (Y4F) variant (this structure) are very similar. The hydroxyl group of p4Y forms a hydrogen bond with the NH1 atom of R155. The pY4F mutation breaks this hydrogen bond, allowing the R155 side chain to take a slightly different conformation, with the Nε atom moving 1.4 Å toward the C terminus of the peptide. The loss of the hydroxyl group also affects the side chain of residue E152, which forms a hydrogen bond with the tyrosine hydroxyl in the H-2Kb/gp33 index peptide structure, While, in general, the pY4F substitution does not result in any major structural changes at the MHC/peptide interface besides subtle movements of α2 TCR contact residues.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: There are four complexes in the asymmetric unit.

ThreeDimensionalStructureOfComplex.Comments: "In the H-2Db/gp33 complex [PDB: 1S7U], both residues p4Y and p6F project out of the peptide binding cleft, acting as potential main TCR contacts. The escape mutants pY4F [PDB: 1S7X] and pF6L [PDB: 1S7V] could thus be explained by impaired TCR recognition rather than by impaired MHC binding. However, the structural impacts of these two conservative substitutions are different. The pY4F mutation does not result in any modifications other than the removal of the tyrosine hydroxyl group, whereas the conserved pF6L substitution results in changes in the potential TCR contact residues that probably affect the sensitive regions of the TCR through direct sterical clashes and/or the introduction of cavities at the TCR/pMHC interface. The pF6L mutation results in shifts in the central portion variant peptide (residues p4 to p7). In contrast, the crystal structures of H-2Db/index gp33 and H-2Db/gp33 (Y4F) are remarkably similar. Thus, the only significant difference between the two structures is the removal of the tyrosine hydroxyl group at p4 in the mutant escape peptide. Nonetheless, this minor structural difference leads to a 100-fold decrease in binding affinity of the p14 TCR, specific for H-2Db/index gp33."

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Mutant peptide Y4F bound to H-2Kb on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.
Mutant peptide Y4F bound H-2Db on RMA-S TAP-deficient cells.
